Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The generation of a biodiversity hotspot: paleobiogeography of the Caribbean inferred from multiple arachnid lineages with differing dispersal abilities
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Caribbean region is a well-known hotspot of biological diversity, yet the detailed processes that generated this rich species diversity on the islands are complex and poorly understood. This project unites a team of international experts to test hypotheses about how the age and dispersal ability of various species, and the geological history of islands, interplay to generate biodiversity hotspots. The research will also test the importance of islands as sources of continental colonization, and the role of dispersal versus geological land-bridges in island colonization. This will be accomplished by surveying 15 diverse arachnid lineages and their fossil relatives, and by using phylogenetic approaches to analyze patterns of evolutionary relationships, ages of divergence, and patterns of community composition across islands.

A mega-transect across one of the world's most biologically rich archipelagos will transform knowledge of the history of the Caribbean. Many new scientists will be trained -- the project will recruit and train young diversity specialists at multiple institutions, with the central focus at the minority-serving University of Puerto Rico. These biologists will be trained in the importance of educating the public about biodiversity. The work will generate rich resources for further biodiversity research by making species data, phylogenies, range maps, specimen photographs, databases, and DNA sample data publicly available through the internet and museum depositories.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Evolutionary processes interplaying with the earths ever-changing geology have generated the diversity of life. Modern distributions of species provide clues about the historical processes that have influenced the distribution and diversification of the lineages from which they originated. The study of these processes is biogeography.  With this funding a collaborative team centered at University of Vermont and Lewis & Clark College has been analyzing biogeographical patterns of multiple Caribbean arachnid lineages . Arachnids, including spiders, scorpions and their kin, are good models for studying biogeography because they are abundant, small, and diverse. They also have range in dispersal abilities. Some can effectively fly by ballooning, while may move only a few feet in their lifetime. The central goal of our project is to infer fundamental processes that have generated biodiversity in general, and specifically the Caribbean biodiversity hotspot. The Caribbean is home to extraordinarily high numbers of species only known from the region (endemic). It is also subject to high levels of threat to species because of habitat loss. Given increasing extinction rates in areas with little knowledge of species diversity, we are at risk of losing species before we know they exist. Each of these species has value, helping us infer the history of the tree of life.

 

Through this project we have successfully completed the first large-scale inventory of arachnid diversity in the Caribbean and surrounding regions (Fig 1). We have collected, georeferenced and curated roughly 150,000 arachnid specimens.  We are discovering a large number of new species and will minimally add ~1000 newly discovered species to museum collections. Some we have already, or are in the process of describing. With these efforts and specimens we (1) unified world experts with regional arachnologist around systematic analyses of lineages; (2) expanded known ranges of orders, families, genera and species of multiple arachnid lineages, and calliphorid flies (blow flies); (3) estimated patterns of relationships (phylogenies), and inferred biogeographic histories for multiple lineages. We have published multiple papers related to this project and reported biogeographic analyses of seven genera.

 

WE are uncovering parallel patterns among lineages revealing some general processes that have influenced arachnid diversity in the Caribbean region. The strength and consistency of these patterns suggests they are fundamental principles that govern diversification of lineages. First, many lineages of arachnids have an old presence on the Caribbean islands and are more diverse. than what was previously thought. With fossil-dated molecular phylogenies we can infer that multiple lineages, colonized the Caribbean and North American from South America via a proto-Caribbean land bridge that is proposed between 32-35 MYA (GAARLandia) (Fig 2). These lineages subsequently underwent radiation in the region. Similar patterns occur in numerous  lineages that are intermediate to poor dispersers. In stark contrast, good dispersers show patterns of more recent colonization and ongoing movement among islands, with very limited regional diversity.

 

A second general pattern is that within the Caribbean,  we find hierarchical nesting of relationships reflecting among islands, and across geological and habitat structured bioregions within islands  Striking among these is ageneral pattern of strong genetic structuring among cave lineages. We propose that caves on islands may intensify diversification rates for those lineages that live in them.

 

A major impact of this work has been to recruit, inspire, and train a new generation of biodiversity researchers. Twenty UPR and UVM, and thirteen Lewis & Clark College undergraduates have participated in this research. Of these, seventeen are coauthors on published manuscripts and many more are working on manuscripts to be submitted soon. Sixteen are in graduate school (more than half doing biodiversity research) and four have received NSF Predoctoral Fellowships. The theses of six graduate students in the Agnarsson lab (two now graduated) focuses wholly or in part on this project. Graduate students in several other labs also work with the specimens from this project. Five postdocs have worked or are working on this project, all are currently employed in academia.

 

Though major goals of this project have been achieved, massive ongoing work continues with the collected data, forming a major focus of both labs for the coming years. Discovery and description of new species, analyses of biogeographical patterns, and comparative phylogeographical studies are all ongoing. A synthesis comparing patterns across dozens of lineages is anticipated to have a major impact on the field. Further funding is being sought to expand on this work, as major new insights and questions have resulted from our ongoing research.

 

All specimens and genomic DNAs are available by loan and will be archived in museum collections. Sequences linked to verified species are being submitted to the Barcode of Life database to help with future arachnid identifications. Phylogenies and datasets will be submitted to the AVATOL Open Tree of Life Databases, and available for scientists and educators.
